The nasi lemak costs just $1 a packet but you have to get to Jamaliah Osman's Bishan food stall early to get some because it sells out fast. The mother of three was struggling to make ends meet, because her injured husband could not work. Then she heard of a microcredit scheme offering loans to poor people with a viable plan to start a business. She borrowed $7,000 last December and opened SJ Muslim Food in the food court above the Bishan Bus Interchange and she has not looked back.  "I don't have to worry about money any more," she says. Theresa Tan reports in The Sunday Times on the small loans scheme that has helped people like Madam Jamaliah get a new start in life.

The Standard Chartered Marathon Singapore on Dec 2 will see runners raising funds for a variety of good causes. But Eugene Lim (left in the photo) and his friend Kenneth Lim have had horrific toilet experiences travelling in Asia and want you to know that too many people in the world do not have clean loos. So they will be running the half marathon to raise funds for the World Toilet Organisation. About 2.5 billion people in the world  do not have access to proper sanitation and it's serious because it means diseases spread and children die. Read about Eugene, Kenneth and other runners for a cause in The Sunday Times.

What a cutie pie! Wildlife photographer Bjorn Oleson tells Wong Kim Hoh in The Sunday Times: "It's not very well known but 50 per cent of the time, giant pandas give birth to twins. In the wild, one of them dies because the mother can care for only one baby." But researchers at a breeding centre in China found a way to save the abandoned cub, swopping it regularly with its twin so that the mother suckled both. "I took the picture when he was about to be swopped with his twin. He looked so cute, sitting in his basket, not knowing he was going to see his mother," says Mr Oleson. He and his wife, Ms Fanny Lai, have written a book, A Visual Celebration Of Giant Pandas, to raise awareness about pandas and raise funds for the World Wildlife Fund.

Well, 20 lucky readers of The Straits Times will get to do so, thanks to our friends at Wildlife Reserves Singapore. This is part of our Straits Times Appreciates Readers programme. All you have to do is take part in a simple contest (details in the paper tomorrow) and you could join an exclusive preview of the panda exhibit. And you'll get to spend more time than the 15 minutes that other visitors will be restricted to when the exhibit opens to the public on Nov 29.      ST Photo by Desmond Foo

Thousands of gamers here turned up in full force at the Funan DigitaLife Mall today to be among the first in the world to get their hands on the latest version of the hit Halo series, Halo 4.

For more pictures, go to http://bit.ly/THJzpz

-- ST PHOTO: SEAH KWANG PENG

Mr Greg Gayheart, a volunteer with the Licking County Board of Elections, loads voting machines in preparation for election day in Newark, Ohio on Nov 3, 2012. Licking County has nearly 600 voting machines for 125 voting precincts. 

The following images at http://bit.ly/VxhZxu show volunteers setting up equipment ahead of election day in various parts of the United States.

--PHOTO: REUTERS

Thousands of music fans clogged a Boston street on Monday to hear Grammy award-winning rock band Aerosmith perform a free concert in front of the apartment building where the musicians began their career four decades ago.

For the full story, go to: http://bit.ly/RF3TWn

-- PHOTO: AP

What would Lea Salonga do, as a mother, if her child was bullied on the playground?

 The protective, maternal side of Salonga emerges, and she exclaims: "I honestly don't know! My kneejerk reaction is to go after the kid that beat up my kid. Or go after the parents: 'Your kid beat up my kid! You have to pay for the hospital, you have to pay for the doctors, you have to pay for whatever.'

For more on Tony and Olivier award winner who stars in God Of Carnage which open tomorrow, go to ST's interactive Entertainment community: http://bit.ly/VtXRMG

--PHOTO: SINGAPORE REPERTORY THEATRE

The five-yearly party congress meeting is the most important political event on the Chinese Communist Party calendar. 

The Straits Times' (ST) senior writer Ching Cheong shares his thoughts on the 18th Party Congress in a video interview with ST's Hong Kong correspondent Li Xueying.

To view the video, go to: http://bit.ly/PRnxS3

Around 400 undergraduates took part in an online poll where one of the questions was whether they feel there is a need for an Internet code of conduct.

The results:
39.1 per cent said it would be good to have such a code while 17 per cent said "yes, absolutely"
link_name: Undergraduates support an online code of conduct?

status_message:
This should have been called The Fierce Wife concert.

 The hit Taiwanese series from 2010, about a woman whose marriage crumbles when her husband has an affair with her distant relative, not only made household names of the main leads Sonia Sui and James Wen. It also lifted Freya Lim and Yisa Yu, the singers behind the soundtrack, out of obscurity.

Read more on the concert on ST's interactive Entertainment Community and share your views at: http://bit.ly/TsyKD6

--PHOTO: ROCK RECORDS

Kimi Raikkonen won a thrilling Abu Dhabi Grand Prix for Lotus here on Sunday with Fernando Alonso of Ferrari taking second and Sebastian Vettel a remarkable third after setting off from the back of the grid.

For the full story, go to: http://bit.ly/R7C8FS

-- PHOTO: AFP

Water-damaged furniture and belongings are piled high on sand along East Avenue in the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy, at Bay Head, New Jersey, Nov 4, 2012.

For more images of happenings around the world in the last 24 hours, go to: http://bit.ly/Vs3bju

-- PHOTO: REUTERS

Stars gathered at the Saban Theatre on Saturday, Nov 3, 2012, in Beverly Hills, California for Eddie Murphy: One Night Only,  a celebration of Eddie Murphy's career. 

"I am a very, very bitter man," Murphy said with a beguiling smile. "I don't get touched easily, and I am really touched." 

For the full story and more, check out ST's new interactive Entertainment Community: http://bit.ly/TtfrM9

Beijing issued its second-highest blizzard alert on Sunday after the Chinese capital was hit by an unusually early snowstorm four days before the start of a key political meeting.

In the 24 hours until Sunday morning, the city saw 5.8cm of precipitation (rain and snow combined), the highest daily total for any cold season since 1951, the Xinhua news agency said.

For more pictures, go to http://bit.ly/SpKaJl

--PHOTO: REUTERS

JJ Lin's title ballad from his latest album, Lost N Found, was named among the Top 20 Hits Of The Year at the 12th Global Chinese Music Awards.

Is that your favourite of all his songs?

Tell us which JJ Lin song you like the most on ST's new interactive Entertainment Community, which comprises Movies, Music, TV and Show: http://bit.ly/TCV3uw

-- ST PHOTO: DESMOND WEE

New Zealand tourism chiefs are hoping to recreate the surge in visitors inspired by the original The Lord Of The Rings trilogy.

They have launched a massive marketing campaign around director Peter Jackson's new The Hobbit movie trilogy, including this giant, bug-eyed Gollum sculpture looming over passengers at Wellington Airport.

For the full story and more, check out ST's new interactive Entertainment Community: http://bit.ly/Qf1cOg

-- PHOTO: AFP

Shaun Choo may look like any other clean-cut national serviceman. But the 21-year-old pianist recently claimed top prize at the 2nd Asia-Pacific International Chopin Piano Competition in Daegu, South Korea, on October 26. The prize money of 20,000 euros (S$31,520) will go straight to funding his education.

Choo says he could have easily skipped out on NS, renounced his Singapore citizenship and taken up an Austrian one. But while he despaired at the possible lack of practice and the trauma his hands might face, he chose to return to Singapore.

Read the full story, and more, on ST Communities: http://bit.ly/SJlzSW

Seventy years ago, 50,000 captured Allied soldiers were forced by the Japanese to make a long march to Changi Prison on Nov 3, 1942.

On Saturday, members of Sandbag, an association of former British and Commonwealth military personnel based in Singapore and the surrounding region, retraced the route by organising a 21km walk from the Padang to Changi Chapel.

Read more about their journey in the pouring rain here: http://bit.ly/SJf5Ui

ST Photo: Desmond Wee

After cabby Muhammad Hasnor Hashim told The Sunday Times on Oct 28 that he earned $7,000 a month driving a Premier taxi, he was attacked by many who felt that sum was beyond any cabby's reach. Now he has changed his story. Now he's no longer driving a Premier taxi, saying other drivers were unhappy with him. Transport Correspondent Maria Almenoar, who was also flamed online for her report, tells why Mr Muhammad appeared truthful when he spoke to her and photojournalist Seah Kwan Peng. He and another cabby, Mark Leow, who said he earned $6,000 a month, described how they did it and were prepared to show others how to do it too. "What the two cabbies revealed appeared to be a starting point to find out how other cabbies could earn more than the current $2,000 average," she says.

It was a gangfight that left teenager Darren Ng dead and several others arrested for their part in the senseless tragedy two years ago. Madam Chen Siew Lan's son is among those in jail. He was 14 when he came home with a tattoo across his chest and she knew he was heading for trouble.At least her son is alive. Darren's mother lives only with memories and pain. JOYCE LIM reports on the grief of two mothers in The Sunday Times.

As a schoolboy Toh Chin Siong was too busy helping his father in the karung guni trade to be any good at his studies. He ended up in the rag-and-bone business himself. He tells WONG KIM HOH about his ups and downs, people who cheated him and others who helped him. He remembers a cancer patient who sold off his rare rosewood desks to pay for his treatment, and an old man who wept when his grand Chinese medicine chests were dismantled and taken away. Read his fascinating story in The Sunday Times.

Singapore's a great place for runners, and they keep finding new and interesting routes to take them off the beaten track. 
CHERYL FAITH WEE asks the faithful to name the routes with the most stunning views. Check them out in The Sunday Times.

Don't kid yourself. Singapore's not a clean city. It's a "cleaned city", says the man in charge of the stop littering campaign. "Places like Japan, Korea, Scandinavia and Taiwan, they are always clean, always dry, without an army of cleaners. Look at us: we're dirty as hell. We throw something on the ground, it miraculously disappears," says Mr Liak Teng Lit. He tells CHANG AI-LIEN Singapore has to get tough with its incorrigible litterbugs and he has a long list of ideas to bring about change, in The Sunday Times.

ST Life!'s Wong Ah Yoke, visits Majestic Bay Seafood Restaurant and recommends one of its dim sums: a bun filled with chilli crabmeat. "It's not the same as eating chilli crab but tastes good in its own way. Plus, you don't need to dirty your fingers peeling crab shells." -- PHOTO: MAJESTIC BAY SEAFOOD RESTAURANT 

Read the full review here: http://bit.ly/Sn5wHa

Island living goes gourmet with a new stretch of restaurants slated to open at Sentosa Cove's Quayside Isle by the first quarter of next year. -- ST PHOTO: MUGILAN RAJASEGERAN

More pictures + full story http://bitly.com/TZCFYW

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers believes there is plenty to come from Steven Gerrard as he prepares to make his 600th appearance for the club, against Newcastle at Anfield on Sunday.

See more pictures of what went on around the world in the past week here: http://bit.ly/U5OkLy

Korean pop quartet 2NE1 surprised about 2,000 local fans on Friday night when they appeared on a makeshift stage at Clarke Quay to perform five songs.

Ryan Giggs has hailed the impact of Robin van Persie as the Manchester United striker prepares to face his former club Arsenal for the first time since moving to Old Trafford in August. 

Here are some statistics ahead of the Manchester United v Arsenal match on Saturday.

He'll be playing in a title-deciding game tomorrow for the Tampines Rovers, but that's not stopping Aleksandar Duric from continuing his charity drive. 

He has turned chauffeur to help raise funds for The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund and will do so until Sunday. 

If you would like to support his charity drive, here's how: 
- Email stsportsmatters@sph.com.sg with your full name and contact number.
- Include pick-up details i.e. from Point A to Point B (with full addresses) and specify the time you need to be picked up.
- There is a minimum donation of $100 for each trip (within Singapore only). 
- A minimum of 24 hours' notice is required
- Bookings are subject to availability and match times
- A maximum of four passengers per trip

Available times: 7.30am-3.30pm and 8pm-10pm

ST Photo: Desmond Lim

Former All Blacks captain Tana Umaga sat down with The Straits Times today to talk about which sides he thinks will be fierce competitors at the 2016 Olympics. Read tomorrow's ST to find out who he thinks will be the frontrunners.

The 39-year-old is in Singapore as an ambassador for the Singapore Cricket Club International Sevens, which starts tomorrow. It will run alongside the HSBC Asian Sevens, a qualifier to the World Cup in Moscow next year. 

Umaga also took some time to conduct a clinic for 250 students today at the Padang. It is his first time back in Singapore since 1998. 

He was amazed at how much the Marina area has transformed since then, and even pointed out to the new Supreme Court building and said: "That UFO-looking thing wasn't there the last time."

Golf superstar Tiger Woods is in Singapore again, and he was at the Marina Bay Sands this evening for a putting clinic with 12 youngsters from the Singapore Sports School. The world No 2 is here for a short private visit.

"Politics is insistent in its claim on your time and in its demands on one's nervous energy. That part, I don't really miss. Because I have more freedom now, less of that constant pressure."

- Former Foreign Minister George Yeo

Read more from this exclusive interview in The Straits Times today as well as on Singapolitics.sg
link_name: George Yeo looks back with "mixed feelings"

Trade and industry partners were treated to a preview screening for latest Bond flick Skyfall last night at Shaw Lido, and sent in their movie reviews to be published on our new ST Entertainment Community. 

Their reviews were mostly positive, but our resident movie critic John Lui called it "overhyped". If you're catching Skyfall from today, join the Community and send in your movie reviews if you disagree with John Lui.

Join the Community at: http://stcommunities.straitstimes.com/

Pedestrians running for shelter from the rain in Orchard Road around noon on Wednesday. 

Flash floods hit several parts of Singapore on Wednesday, even as government agencies geared up for heavy rain during the annual north-east monsoon season. Is this the start of the flash-floods season again?

Videos shown in court on Wednesday cast doubt over Thai teenager Nitcharee Peneakchanasak's claim that she had felt passengers' close contact before she lost her balance and fell onto the train tracks.

The videos, comprising platform security camera footage, showed fewer than 30 people on the platform of Ang Mo Kio station in April last year.

Workers place a coffin into an apartment-style grave at the Navotas Municipal Cemetery in Manila.

The National University of Singapore (NUS) scholar, who made headlines recently for posting an explicit sex blog, has apologised to the school.

A review of the Primary School Leaving Examination is underway, said Education Minister Heng Swee Keat. 

However, he stressed that the exam should not be viewed "in isolation", but as part of a broader review of the education system. "This is not a short-term quick fix," he noted.

What changes do you think should be made to the PSLE?

Read more here: http://bit.ly/VCH1GF

To mark the 50th anniversary of the first 007 film, Dr. No, a variety of James Bond memorabilia, including the Aston Martin V12 DBS coupe used in the film, Quantum Of Solace, went under the hammer in London on Oct 5.

Have a look at the pictures and more at ST's new interactive Entertainment Community: http://bit.ly/TmdS0k

The Sengkang Punggol LRT system will be upgraded from a one-car to two-car train system by 2016 to cater to increasing ridership, Minister of State for Transport Josephine Teo announced on Wednesday.

The LTA will modify 16 of the existing 41 single-car trains to be coupled for two-car operations. It will also buy 16 more train cars, increasing the train fleet of by about 40 per cent. What do you think of these changes? 

Read more here: http://bit.ly/VCB9gy

ST Photo: Nuria Ling

Singer Stefanie Sun has given birth to her first child, a boy, on Oct 30.

According to a statement from a Stefanie Sun spokesman, the singer went to the hospital on Tuesday afternoon and gave birth later that night. Both mother and son are well.

Read the full story here: http://bit.ly/StZEzg

Photo: Courtesy of Stefanie Sun

Disney will buy George Lucas' film studio, including the Star Wars franchise, in a US$4 billion deal that will also see more films in the legendary sci-fi series. 

Star Wars 7 will be released in 2015, "with more feature films expected to continue the Star Wars saga and grow the franchise well into the future," said the Walt Disney Co in an announcement for the deal. 

Good news, Star Wars fans, or do you have a bad feeling about this? Let us know over on our new Entertainment Community. 

Read the full story here: http://bit.ly/Rrzv35

Six actors have taken on the iconic role of suave agent James Bond to date.

Have a look at them and tell us who you think is the best Bond on ST's new interactive Entertainment Community: http://bit.ly/Sux7bD

-- PHOTO: AP

A head-teacher in the Georgian city of Rustavi has found an unusual way to get children's early education off the ground - by transforming an aeroplane into a kindergarten.

Mr Gari Chapidze bought the old but fully functional Yakovlev Yak-42 from Georgian Airways and refurbished its interior with educational equipment, games and toys but left the cockpit instruments intact so they could be used as play tools.

For more pictures, go to http://bit.ly/Sd92ob

Love and marriage Singapore style? It's changing, reports  Theresa Tan, from looking at the latest marriage statistics. Several trends are taking root. Among them: more Singapore men are marrying women from other Asian countries; more Chinese brides have Caucasian grooms; more men are marrying older women; and there are more remarriages as divorced people give love a second chance. It's some happy news for a change. Hope you pick up the paper this Sunday!

You just gotta love these bears. Travel Writer Lee Siew Hua goes to Chengdu in Sichuan, the land of lolling pandas. Yes, they are adorable, and she discovers there's much more to see and do. Read her story in the SundayLife! section of The Sunday Times.

You can't tell from this happy picture that Jimmy Ong has been to hell and back. He tells Senior Writer Wong Kim Hoh how he went from having it all to bankruptcy and the brink of suicide. Amazingly,  the secondary school dropout pulled his life together again. Read his inspiring story in The Sunday Times.

Red Bull Racing's Sebastian Vettel successfully defended his Singapore Formula One crown in one of the most thrilling editions, as the German made the most of Lewis Hamilton's early retirement to enhance his own championship chances.

If you've ever suffered a hard drive crash, this is for you. 

Hitachi on Monday unveiled a method of storing digital information on slivers of quartz glass that can endure extreme temperatures and hostile conditions without degrading, almost forever. Current digital media, such as CDs and hard drives, have a life span of a few decades or a century at most.

Straits Times reader Ms Ng Wai Meng argues that for some, neighbourhood schools may be the best option. She said that while some students may not be as academically inclined as those in "branded" schools, they may have different strengths, such as in entrepreneurship, sports, music or the arts.

"Ultimately, parents should know the strengths of their children and ensure that they have happy school lives, by not comparing them to other children, or pushing them to enter "branded" schools," she added. What do you think it will take to make neighbourhood schools "acceptable" to pushy parents?

TODAY IN PICTURES | SEPT. 7, 2012: People covered in black grease celebrate the traditional festivities of Cascamorras, in Baza, near Granada. Every year on September 6, a villager from Guadix dresses as an oddball character called 'Cascamorras' and travels the 3km to the village of Baza, accompanied by a team of representatives, to stage an attempt to recapture the statue of the Virgen de la Piedad. The people of Baza dirty their faces and wait with coloured water and eggs to pelt the intruders, thus staining the clothes of Cascamorras and ensuring his failure. (AFP PHOTO/JORGE GUERRERO)

By Warren Fernandez, Editor
As you head out to lunch, many of you often have a peek at your Facebook to catch up on what's happening around you. My colleagues and I at The Straits Times will strive to keep you posted on major developments that might interest you, as well as stories we are working on. Today, this ranges from an update on the haze that has hit Singapore and what this might mean for your weekend plans, to a special report on how we might improve work-life balance in Singapore companies. Through the Lens: A military funeral is held for the late Lance-Corporal (LCP) Muhammad Fahrurrazi Bin Salim, 20, at Choa Chu Kang Muslim cemetery on August 14, 2012. His body was found at 2.55am on 14 August 2012 in the Sungai Batu Apoi river,Temburong. One of the Singapore Armed Forces search parties, which had continued the search throughout the night, found LCP Fahrurrazi's body about 200 metres from where he was first reported missing. The body was flown back to Singapore in the afternoon via a Republic of Singapore Air Force C-130 transport plane for the military funeral. Photo: Desmond Wee / The Straits Times. BRONZE MEDAL FOR SINGAPORE!!! 

Wang Yuegu and Li Jiawei steamrolls their way through and take the doubles against South Korea's Seok Ha Jung and Dang Ye Seo 11-9, 11-6, 6-11, 11-5!

The women's table tennis team wins the tie in a comprehensive 3-0 victory. This is Singapore's second bronze medal at this Games. Feng Tianwei won an bronze in the singles last week.

It was a nervy finish in the end, but team captain Feng Tianwei takes Singapore into the lead with a 11-9, 11-8, 4-11, 13-11 win over defensive specialist Kim Kyung Ah of South Korea. 

Next up: Li Jiawei vs Seok Ha Jung in the second singles. Singapore is 1-0 in the lead in the bronze medal match.

status_message: President-designate Tony Tan said the presidential campaign reflected the political maturity of Singapore. "Now that it's over, we should all unite, put aside our political affiliations. The President is above politics."

PM Lee Hsien Loong on the 2011 Presidential Election final result:

Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said voters faced a difficult choice between Dr Tony Tan and Dr Tan Cheng Bock, and this explained why the winning margin was so narrow.

How many votes Tony Tan won by: 
Dr Tony Tan is the 7th President of Singapore, beating closest rival Dr Tan Cheng Bock by 7,269 votes.
The next President of Singapore is announced: Dr Tony Tan with 744,397 votes. Dr Tan Cheng Bock with 737,128 votes. Dr Tony Tan beat Dr Tan Cheng Bock.

Dr Tan Cheng Bock continues: He thanks all his various teams, from social media, to translators, to fundraisers. His camp ate, laughed, fought together. Even those with different political affiliations came together. He said he believes they all put the nation above politics, to come together. He is very proud of them.

Dr Tan Cheng Bock speaking live now to his supporters: The results of the recount still not known, asks them to be patient. He thanks voters who supported him, he made good friends and is grateful to all. He said his camp did the best they could.
Alert: Returning Officer Yam Ah Mee has emerged from his office at the Elections Department in his suit. He says the recount is "finishing".

Dr Tan Cheng Bock's wife Cecilia has asked supporters to go home to 
await the results of the recount. The recount will take about three to four hours, she said.
Sources have said that Dr Tony Tan is leading with just 7,600 votes over Dr Tan Cheng Bock.
Elections Dept: The two candidates with the most votes are TT and TCB. The difference is not more than 2%. There will be a recount.
Tan Jee Say's election, polling and counting agent Jeanette Chong-Aruldoss says that he is likely to get his $48,000 back.
Tan Jee Say is not conceding defeat, but asks supporters who are tired to go home and rest.
Dr Tan Cheng Bock's son, Joshua, told The Straits Times that from unofficial tallies, his father is leading by "a couple of percentage points".
A member of Tan Jee Say's campaign told The Straits Times that they hope to win but are also prepared to lose: "In every contest there is always a winner and a loser."

The Straits Times also reports that according to sources within his camp, Dr Tan Cheng Bock is leading by as much as 8 per cent over Dr Tony Tan in the West. However, Dr Tony Tan is leading in the East and Central areas including counting centres such as SCGS, RJC,  Tao Nan and Hwa Chong JC. In fact, the numbers are so close that it may result in a recount. Candidates may request for a recount of the votes at the counting centres if the difference between the votes is 2 per cent or less.

The Straits Times can report that with a third of the votes in, it looks like the race is between Dr Tony Tan and Dr Tan Cheng Bock, with the difference as close as little as 1 per cent. Based on unconfirmed reports streaming in from the counting centres, Dr Tan Cheng Bock holds the slight edge over Dr Tony Tan, bolstered by a strong showing in counting centres in the West.
Dr Tan Cheng Bock has just arrived at the Elections Department and is the first candidate to do so tonight.

Recount possible? Tony Tan and Tan Cheng Bock joint leaders in count
A source from Tan Cheng Bock's campaign has said these are the overall results:
Tony Tan: 35%, Tan Cheng Bock: 35%, Tan Jee Say: 25% and Tan Kin Lian: 5%
There might be a recount, and a tabulation of results from overseas voters.
A source in Dr Tan Cheng Bock's camp told The Straits Times that these are the islandwide figures so far: Dr Tan Cheng Bock (35.4%), Dr Tony Tan (33.1), Mr Tan Jee Say (25.1), Mr Tan Kin Lian (4.7)

Tan Kin Lian's wife Vivian, 55, told The Straits Times: "I told him we've already won. I feel proud of him. Everything he's wanted to say and do, he's already done. We've made a contribution to the country."
A source has said that in the East, Tan Cheng Bock and Tony Tan are neck and neck, but Tan Cheng Bock is leading by 4 per cent in the West.

Mr Tan Kin Lian has conceded defeat in the race to become Singapore's seventh president. Outside Anderson Primary School at 10.10pm, Mr Tan put on a brave face and said it will be a close fight between "the top two". Asked whether he will get his election deposit back, he said "Maybe not". He will not be going to the Elections Department, but straight home, before he meets friends and supporters nearby. He said it has been a "good experience" and maybe they will do better next time.
A reliable source has told The Straits Times that overall, Tony Tan has a slim lead. over Tan Cheng Bock. It is going to be a close call.
Tan Kin Lian has conceded.
Counting source: Tan Cheng Bock leading by 10% in West.
Tan Cheng Bock leading in the West: A source at a counting centre in Western Singapore says Dr Tan Cheng Bock has about 70 per cent of votes so far.

Sources from various counting stations around the island put Dr Tony Tan in the lead, in the race to be Singapore's seventh president. Unconfirmed reports from one centre have him at about 40 per cent, with both Dr Tan Cheng Bock and Mr Tan Jee Say below 30 per cent. Mr Tan Kin Lian is said to have about 10 per cent of the votes.
Sources are also saying that Dr Tan Cheng Bock is enjoying strong support in the western and north-eastern part of Singapore.

Tony Tan and Tan Cheng Bock 'close to each other' in counting at Bedok: 
An unconfirmed source from a counting centre in Bedok says it
is very close between Dr Tony Tan and Dr Tan Cheng Bock. Mr Tan Jee
Say is not too far behind.

Confirmed: PAP wins Jurong GRC. PAP: 76,489 votes. NSP: 37,734 votes. #SGelections
Low thanks S'poreans for their "leap of faith", for wanting "a home and not just a house". #SGelections
"You have made history tonight!" - WP chief Low Thia Khiang to the cheering crowd at Hougang Stadium. #SGelections
The whole of Hougang Stadium is on its feet and cheering, fists pumping the air, as the Aljunied GRC results are announced. #SGelections
Confirmed: WP wins Aljunied GRC. WP: 72,165 votes. PAP: 59,732 votes. #SGelections
At Hougang Stadium, WP's Nee Soon GRC team announces that the WP team in Aljunied has won. #SGelections
Confirmed: PAP wins Holland-Bukit Timah GRC. PAP: 48,682 votes. SDP: 32,322 votes. #SGelections
Confirmed: PAP wins Nee Soon GRC. PAP: 80,659 votes. WP: 57,482 votes. #SGelections
Confirmed: PAP wins Sembawang GRC. PAP: 84,185 votes. SDP: 47,578 votes. #SGelections
Confirmed: PAP wins East Coast GRC. PAP: 59,895 votes. WP: 49,342 votes. #SGelections

Our sources said the PAP got less than 50 per cent of the vote in every one of the five divisions in Aljunied GRC, said to have been won by WP. Serangoon gave PAP the lowest vote share, followed by Paya Lebar, then Kaki Bukit and Hougang-Bedok Reservoir and finally Eunos.
For more on PAP's victory in Ang Mo Kio, go to
Confirmed: PAP wins Bishan-Toa Payoh GRC. PAP: 62,282 votes. SPP: 47,092 votes. #SGelections
For more on the PAP's victory in Hong Kah North, go to
link_name: Amy Khor wins Hong Kah North

status_message: Confirmed: PAP wins Ang Mo Kio GRC. PAP: 112,544 votes. Reform Party: 49,779 votes. #SGelections
For more about the Worker's Party's victory in Hougang, go to
At Bedok Stadium, Mah Bow Tan thanks Tampines residents for "strong mandate". More live updates at http://is.gd/msTvEu #SGelections
WP's Aljunied team is being garlanded at Hougang Stadium. View our live updates at http://is.gd/msTvEu #SGelections
Confirmed: PAP wins West Coast GRC. PAP: 72,465 votes. Reform Party: 36,395 votes. #SGelections
Confirmed: PAP wins Tampines GRC. PAP: 72,664 votes. NSP: 54,337 votes. #SGelections
Confirmed: PAP wins Pasir Ris-Ponggol GRC. PAP:  100,382 votes. SDA: 54,546 votes. #SGelections
Confirmed: WP wins Hougang SMC. PAP: 8,053 votes. WP: 14,833 votes #SGelections
Confirmed: PAP wins Marine Parade GRC. NSP: 59,833 votes. PAP: 78,182 votes. #SGelections
Looks like recount is done and PAP has taken Potong Pasir. #SGelections
Our reporters say SM Goh is comforting George Yeo, who is still smiling despite his defeat in Aljunied GRC. #SGelections

The bad news is starting to spread among the PAP supporters in the Aljunied section at Bedok Stadium, quiet even as the supporters from Tampines GRC next to them cheer their victorious candidates. One party activist says, we are telling them, not to cry. But one breaks down nevertheless. 'We've worked so hard,' says a 69-year-old activist for Cynthia Phua.
Confirmed:  PAP wins Joo Chiat SMC. PAP: 9,630 WP: 9,248 votes #SGelections
Confirmed: PAP wins Moulmein-Kallang GRC. WP: 31,721votes. PAP: 44,828 votes. #SGelections
Looks like it's a strong win for the PAP at Sembawang GRC. #SGelections
http://www.straitstimes.com/GeneralElection/News/Story/STIStory_666059.html
Looks like there's a recount going on at Potong Pasir. #SGelections
Confirmed: PAP wins Whampoa SMC. PAP: 13,015 votes. NSP: 6,672 votes #SGelections
Confirmed: PAP wins Radin Mas SMC. PAP: 18,591 votes. NSP: 9,110 votes. #SGelections
Indications are that PAP has won Potong Pasir SMC. #SGelections
Confirmed: PAP wins Bukit Panjang SMC. SDP: 10,362 votes. PAP: 20,349 votes. #SGelections
Confirmed: PAP wins Mountbatten SMC. NSP garners 8436 votes. PAP garners 11965 votes. 418 spoilt votes. #SGelections
Looks like Teo Ho Pin has won Bukit Panjang SMC. #SGelections
PAP has won Sengkang West SMC, say our sources. #SGelections
PAP seems to be leading in Marine Parade GRC, say our reporters. #SGelections
PAP seems to be leading by a close margin in East Coast GRC, according to our reporters. #SGelections
Our reporters say that PAP seems to be leading in Bishan-Toa Payoh. #SGelections
PAP takes CCK GRC on a good margin and it looks likely that scholar couple Hazel Poa and Tony Tan will not get NCMP seats. #SGelections
Ms Amy Khor takes Hong Kah North by a wide margin against SPP's Sin Kek Tong, who said he "lost badly". #SGelections
PAP looks set to take Tampines GRC, say our sources. #SGelections
Our reporter tells us Sin Kek Tong has lost badly in Hong Kah North and is heading home. #SGelections
The WP win in Aljunied does not require a recount, said a source. This means winning margin is more than 2 percentage points. #SGelections
WP has won in Aljunied GRC, said one of the 5 PAP candidates. #SGelections
Looks like the PAP has won Choa Chu Kang GRC. #SGelections
George Yeo has left Montfort counting centre. Sources say that they don't need a recount. #SGelections
Teo Soh Lung has conceded defeat to Grace Fu in Yuhua. #SGelections
Sources just told us that Aljunied has gone to WP. This is not confirmed. #SGelections
It appears that Steve Chia has lost in Pioneer - not a close fight #SGelections
Our sources say PAP may be asking for a recount at Hougang. #SGelections
From our reporters at the counting centres, it looks like WP will hold on to Hougang but this is unconfirmed. #SGelections
